member.name: T:Metrics.Utils.IHideObjectMembers
member.summary: Helper interface to cleanup editor visible members on metrics.

member.name: M:Metrics.AdvancedMetricsContext.CompletelyDisableMetrics
member.summary: All metrics operations will be NO-OP. This is useful for measuring the impact of the metrics library on the application. If you think the Metrics library is causing issues, this will disable all Metrics operations.

member.name: M:Metrics.AdvancedMetricsContext.ResetMetricsValues

Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

Description of want the value represents ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .

member.name: M:Metrics.MetricsContext.Counter(System.String,Metrics.Unit,Metrics.MetricTags)
member.summary: A counter is a simple incrementing and decrementing 64-bit integer. Ex number of active requests.
member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all counters in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

member.name: M:Metrics.MetricsContext.Meter(System.String,Metrics.Unit,Metrics.TimeUnit,Metrics.MetricTags)
member.summary: A meter measures the rate at which a set of events occur, in a few different ways. This metric is suitable for keeping a record of now often something happens ( error, request etc ).
member.remarks: The mean rate is the average rate of events. It’s generally useful for trivia, but as it represents the total rate for your application’s entire lifetime (e.g., the total number of requests handled, divided by the number of seconds the process has been running), it doesn’t offer a sense of recency. Luckily, meters also record three different exponentially-weighted moving average rates: the 1-, 5-, and 15-minute moving averages.
member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all meters in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Time unit for rates reporting. Defaults to Second ( occurrences / second ).
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

member.name: M:Metrics.MetricsContext.Histogram(System.String,Metrics.Unit,Metrics.SamplingType,Metrics.MetricTags)
member.summary: A Histogram measures the distribution of values in a stream of data: e.g., the number of results returned by a search.
member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all histograms in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Type of the sampling to use (see SamplingType for details ).
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

member.name: M:Metrics.MetricsContext.Timer(System.String,Metrics.Unit,Metrics.SamplingType,Metrics.TimeUnit,Metrics.TimeUnit,Metrics.MetricTags)
member.summary: A timer is basically a histogram of the duration of a type of event and a meter of the rate of its occurrence. and
member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all timers in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Type of the sampling to use (see SamplingType for details ).
Time unit for rates reporting. Defaults to Second ( occurrences / second ).
Time unit for reporting durations. Defaults to Milliseconds.
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

Is set to true, remove any existing handler.

member.param: Action with will be executed with the exception and a specific message.
Is set to true, remove any existing handler.

member.summary: Register application level, CLR related performance counters as Gauge metrics. This includes: Mb in all heaps, time in GC, exceptions per sec, Threads etc.

member.name: F:Metrics.SamplingType.FavourRecent
member.summary: Sampling will be done with a Exponentially Decaying Reservoir.
member.remarks: A histogram with an exponentially decaying reservoir produces quantiles which are representative of (roughly) the last five minutes of data. It does so by using a forward-decaying priority reservoir with an exponential weighting towards newer data. Unlike the uniform reservoir, an exponentially decaying reservoir represents recent data, allowing you to know very quickly if the distribution of the data has changed. More information about Exponentially Decaying Reservoir

member.name: F:Metrics.SamplingType.LongTerm
member.summary: Sampling will done with a Uniform Reservoir.
member.remarks: A histogram with a uniform reservoir produces quantiles which are valid for the entirely of the histogram’s lifetime. It will return a median value, for example, which is the median of all the values the histogram has ever been updated with. Use a uniform histogram when you’re interested in long-term measurements. Don’t use one where you’d want to know if the distribution of the underlying data stream has changed recently. More information about Exponentially Decaying Reservoir

member.name: F:Metrics.SamplingType.SlidingWindow
member.summary: Sampling will done with a Sliding Window Reservoir. A histogram with a sliding window reservoir produces quantiles which are representative of the past N measurements. More information about Exponentially Decaying Reservoir

member.summary: A meter measures the rate at which a set of events occur, in a few different ways. This metric is suitable for keeping a record of now often something happens ( error, request etc ).
member.remarks: The mean rate is the average rate of events. It’s generally useful for trivia, but as it represents the total rate for your application’s entire lifetime (e.g., the total number of requests handled, divided by the number of seconds the process has been running), it doesn’t offer a sense of recency. Luckily, meters also record three different exponentially-weighted moving average rates: the 1-, 5-, and 15-minute moving averages.

member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all counters in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric. Tags can be string array or comma separated values in a string. ex: tags: "tag1,tag2" or tags: new[] {"tag1", "tag2"}

member.name: M:Metrics.Metric.Histogram(System.String,Metrics.Unit,Metrics.SamplingType,Metrics.MetricTags)
member.summary: A Histogram measures the distribution of values in a stream of data: e.g., the number of results returned by a search.
member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all histograms in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Type of the sampling to use (see SamplingType for details ).
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

member.name: M:Metrics.Metric.Timer(System.String,Metrics.Unit,Metrics.SamplingType,Metrics.TimeUnit,Metrics.TimeUnit,Metrics.MetricTags)
member.summary: A timer is basically a histogram of the duration of a type of event and a meter of the rate of its occurrence. and
member.param: Name of the metric. Must be unique across all timers in this context.
Description of what the is being measured ( Unit.Requests , Unit.Items etc ) .
Type of the sampling to use (see SamplingType for details ).
Time unit for rates reporting. Defaults to Second ( occurrences / second ).
Time unit for reporting durations. Defaults to Milliseconds.
Optional set of tags that can be associated with the metric.

member.name: P:Metrics.Metric.Advanced
member.summary: Exposes advanced operations that are possible on this metrics context.

member.summary: Entrypoint for Global Metrics Configuration.

member.name: P:Metrics.TimerContext.Elapsed

member.name: T:Metrics.TimerValue
member.summary: The value reported by a Timer Metric

member.name: T:Metrics.TimerValueSource
member.summary: Combines the value of the timer with the defined unit and the time units for rate and duration.

member.remarks: The scheduling code is inspired form Daniel Crenna's metrics port https://github.com/danielcrenna/metrics-net/blob/master/src/metrics/Reporting/ReporterBase.cs

member.name: T:Metrics.Utils.Scheduler

Action to execute
